locrel:prc.foaf:Person.foaf:title: Dr
title: [Untitled]
vivo:Dataset.redbox:DataCollectionMethod: Field: We will screen Symbiodinium populations in situ to consider how photosynthetic functional grouping across types is influenced by host taxa/environmental history. Although we can sample for Symbiodinium sp. photosynthetic functional group and identity in situ, we will none-the-less examine in hospite populations via removal of nubbins/small fragments. In doing so, we can collect ancillary data required to reconcile the role ofhost and Symbiodinium sp. properties in driving photosynthetic functional diversity while maximising the assessment scale. Our approach will be to broadly sample: (i) reefs at two depths (upper slope 1 at 8m; deep slope >18m) at both Heron Island and Orpheus Island , which have contrasting environmental lhistories, to maximise host-symbiont diversity coverage; and (ii) scleractinian coral diversity, but focus on species of Acroporidae, Pocilloporidae, Poritidae, Pectinidae and Faviidae that are common across depths/reef sites to maximise coverage of host-symbiont diversity, coral growth morphology (skeletal architecture) and symbiont transmission mode, and differing stress tolerance. To minimise environmental impact, we will not collect more than 25 fragments of 2–5cm fragments per sampling occasion and follow procedures via GBR Marine Park Authority permitting; within this sample number we will replicate for species with high polymorphism (e.g. Seriatopora hysterix) or known to contain the same Symbiodinium sp. type, but of differing physiology, between sites (Acropora tenuis). Water quality parameters will be recorded on each sampling occasion, and light availability at the colony surface from where samples are taken measured using a cosine corrected fiber optic quantum sensor. Lab: We will be using ate of the art transcriptomics and metabolomics to examine the response of Symbiodinium populations to environmental perturbations. These will be supported by state of the art physiological measurements (MIMS, active fluorometry).
vivo:Dataset.redbox:DataAnalysisResource: Custom software associated with all instrumentation.
project.name: New Project
vivo:Dataset.redbox:DataCollectionResour: Field: Cameras, spectrophotometers, fluorometers, respirometry chambers. Laboratory: As for field but also MIMS.
dc:description: The objective of this project is to advance knowledge on the healthy functioning of the coral–algal symbiosis, which defines the response of coral reef ecosystems to worldwide environmental change. Current approaches to address this problem have linked coral health to algal symbiont diversity but have been unable to resolve the fundamental symbiont functional traits that govern this link – the “key performance indicators (KPIs)”. This project plans to couple advanced physiological and functional genomics techniques to transform our understanding of how algal symbiont metabolic KPIs regulate coral growth and stress susceptibility. This may provide new diagnostic capability for the assessment of coral health and may enable us to improve coral reef ecosystem management.
vivo:Dataset.dc.format: Field data: xls, csv, jpeg, mpeg Laboratory data: xls, txt
